subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality
: Bosnia-Herzegovina , Popovo Polje , Pječaljina Pećina ( 44°48’N , 18°56’E )
.
Distribution . France , Switzerland , Italy , Slovenia , Croatia , Bosnia and Herzegovina , Albania , Greece .

Diagnosis ( ♂ ♀ ).
An eyed epigean or locally hypogean
Chthonius
that differs from other species of the
ischnocheles
group in the following combination of characters: anterior margin of carapace with 2 (rarely 1) preocular microsetae on each side; posterior margin of carapace with 2 macrosetae and mostly with 1 lateral microseta on each side; chelicerae with 3 (rarely 2) lateral microsetae; chela length 0.73–1.18 mm ; movable chelal finger length 0.46–0.77 mm ; fixed and movable chelal fingers with 32–54 and 23–47 teeth respectively; chelal fingers with reclined, pointed, and moderately spaced teeth; both fixed and movable chelal fingers with 5–8 teeth occupying 0.1 mm at level of est-ist and st-t , distance between successive apices
0.011 –0.023 mm
; movable chelal finger with coupled sensilla pc not on a tubercle; ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 1.1–1.45.

Type material examined
. BOSNIA and HERZEGOVINA — Ravno —“Piecaljna Pečina, b. Popovo-Polje”, “Balkan”, “
Chthonius densedentatus
n. sp. det. Beier / Type ! ♀ ” ( NHMW )
.

Description of adults ( ♂ ♀ ).
Integument strongly pigmented, carapace, tergites, chelicerae and pedipalps reddish brown; marked scale-shaped granulation on lateral surfaces of carapace, on cheliceral palm, on base of pedipalpal femur, on base of fixed and movable chelal fingers and on surface of chelal hand. Carapace ( Figs 98 , 107 ) 0.85–0.95 times longer than broad, trapezoidal, constricted posteriorly; anterior margin denticulate between the median macrosetae and with a prominent epistome ( Figs 97 , 105–106 ); ocular area as in figs 98, 107, anterior eyes with more or less convex lens (diameter 0.035–0.05 mm ), posterior eyes with flat lens or even reduced to a smooth cuticular area, distance from anterior eyes to anterior margin of carapace 0.03–0.05 mm , distance from anterior to posterior eyes 0.05–0.09 mm ; all eyes with a tapetum; standard chaetotaxy mm 4mm :6:4:2:m 2m (24) but highly variable even within populations: anterior row rarely mm 4m or m 4m ; posterior row rarely with two lateral mesosetae (shorter than the median ones) or with a micro– and a mesoseta on each side respectively; posterior row rarely also with m 2mm or mm 2mm or mm2mmm; length of anteromedian macrosetae 0.09–0.16 mm , setae mostly thick. Chaetotaxy of tergites 4:4:4:4:6:6:6:6:1T2T1:4:1T2T1:0. Chaetotaxy of sternites II–X: 9–11:(3)8–9(3):(2)6– 8(2):8:6:6:6:6:2T1T2, sternite II most often with 10 setae; genital opening of males flanked by 5–8 (mainly 6–7) setae on each side. Chelicerae ( Figs 99 , 108 ) 1.9–2.2 times as long as broad, palm with 6 (rarely 7) setae and 3 (rarely 2, as in female holotype ) lateral microsetae (3 and 2 microsetae occur in the same specimen: ♂ from Omisalj, Krk), surface of palm with few non-glandular pores; fixed finger with 2 distal large teeth followed by 5–8 small teeth and 4–6 proximal microtubercles; movable finger with an isolated subapical tooth ( di ) at level with the spinneret, followed by a large tooth and 5–9 teeth proximally reduced in size; gs ratio 0.58–0.64; spinneret wide and semicircular, mainly similar in both sexes ( Figs 99 , 108 ); rallum with 11 blades (11 and 12 blades in ♀ from Grotta Micello, Apulia); serrulae interior and exterior with 14–15 and 16–17 blades respectively. Coxal setae: pedipalp 5 (including 2 on manducatory process), I 3 + 3 marginal microsetae, II 4, III 5, IV 6; coxa I rarely with 3 or 4 + 2 or 3 marginal setae ( ♀ from Omisalj, Krk), coxa III rarely with 6 setae ( ♂ ♀ from Omisalj, Krk); coxa II with 6–13 (mainly 7–8) coxal spines, coxa III with 3–7 (mainly 3–4) coxal spines; intercoxal tubercle bisetose. Pedipalp: femur 4.15–5.1 ( ♂ ) or 3.8–5.25 ( ♀ ) times as long as broad, femoral chaetotaxy 3:6:2:5:1; chela ( Figs 101 , 110 ) 5.1–5.55 ( ♂ ) or 4.45–5.5 ( ♀ ) times as long as deep; hand of chela 1.75–2.05 ( ♂ ) or 1.55–1.95 ( ♀ ) times as long as deep, with parallel sides or with long ovoid outline in dorsal view ( Fig. 100 , 109 ); fixed chelal finger with 35–54 ( ♂ ) or 32–53 ( ♀ ) broad and almost contiguous or slightly widely spaced teeth, cuspidate and inclined backwards, increasingly reduced towards finger base; the 3–7 proximal teeth short and apically rounded ( Figs 102–104 , 111–116 ), followed by 3–6 microtubercles; all teeth with dental canal; fixed finger at level of est-it with 5–7 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.013 –0.018 ( ♂ ) or 0.011 –0.023 ( ♀ ) mm; tip of fixed chelal finger with apical sensilla af
1- 2
, distal paraxial seta gradually curved and thin; movable chelal finger with 27–43 ( ♂ ) or 23–47 ( ♀ ) teeth, reclined and apically pointed in the distal two thirds of the finger, rounded and increasingly reduced from sb towards finger base; the 4–6 proximal teeth indicated only by the presence of dental canals ( Figs 102–104 , 111–116 ); movable finger at level of st-t with 5–8 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.012 –0.018 ( ♂ ) or 0.011 –0.022 ( ♀ ) mm; coupled sensilla pc just distad of sb , rarely at level at sb ; tip of movable chelal finger with apical sensilla am
1- 2
; trichobothria as in figs 101, 110; ratio sb -st/sb -b = 1.7–1.8; ratio of movable finger/hand of chela 1.7–1.95 ( ♂ ) or 1.65–2.0 ( ♀ ); ratio of pedipalpal femur/movable finger 0.95–1.05 ( ♂ ) or 1.0–1.05 ( ♀ ); ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 1.15–1.35 ( ♂ ) or 1.1–1.45 ( ♀ ).

Description of tritonymph. Integument pigmented but hispid granulation less marked than in adults. Carapace 0.9–0.95 times longer than broad, epistome less prominent than in adults; eyes as in adults, diameter of anterior eyes
0.034 –0.037 mm
; chaetotaxy m 4m :6:4:2:m 2m (22), posterior row rarely m2 or m 2mm ; length of anteromedian macrosetae
0.073 –0.080 mm
, all setae thick. Chaetotaxy of tergites as in adults. Chaetotaxy of sternites II–IX 5:(2)8(2):(1)6–8(1):8:6:6:6:6. Chelicerae 1.95–2.0 times as long as broad, palm with 5 setae and 2 (rarely 1 or 3) lateral microsetae; fixed finger with 7–9 teeth, proximally reduced in size, and a few proximal microtubercles; movable finger with an isolated subapical tooth ( di ) and 7–8 teeth; gs ratio 0.56–0.60; spinneret as in adults. Coxal setae: pedipalp 5 (including 2 on manducatory process), I 3 + 2 marginal microsetae, II 4, III 5, IV 5; coxa II with 4–7 coxal spines, coxa III with 3–5 coxal spines; intercoxal tubercle bisetose. Pedipalp: femur 3.75–4.55 times as long as broad; chela 4.6–4.9 times as long as deep; hand of chela 1.65–1.75 times as long as deep; fixed chelal finger with 34–42 slightly spaced teeth, all with dental canal; movable chelal finger with 24–35 teeth, reduced in size towards finger base, reaching back near b ; coupled sensilla pc nearer to b than to st ; ratio of movable finger/hand of chela 1.75–1.9; ratio of pedipalpal femur/movable finger 0.95–1.05; ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 0.95–1.1.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 97–100.
Chthonius densedentatus Beier, 1938
, male, Omisalj (Krk, Croatia). 97, anterior margin of carapace; 98, carapace; 99, right chelicera; 100, right chelal hand, dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Measurements (in mm). Body length 1.0–1.3. Carapace 0.32–0.38 × 0.35–0.42 (0.32–0.37 anteriorly). Chelicerae 0.29–0.34 × 0.145 –0.175 , movable finger length 0.15–0.18. Pedipalp: femur 0.34–0.42 × 0.08–0.10; chela 0.52–0.64 × 0.11–0.135; hand length 0.19–0.225; movable finger length 0.34–0.42.

Remarks. The examination of the female holotype of
Chthonius densedentatus
revealed a notable derivation from Beier (1938 , 1939 ) who reported 36 teeth for the movable chelal finger (28 from my observations). This difference may be caused by the condition of the preserved specimen and the consequent difficulty in detecting the dental canal of the reduced proximal teeth. The holotype redescription allowed to confirm the presence of two preocular microsetae on each side and of two lateral microsetae on cheliceral palm, as well as the dentition pattern of the chelal fingers ( Figs 114–116 ).

Chthonius ruffoi
, described by Caporiacco (1951a) from Zinzulusa Cave ( Apulia ), represents a population of recent subterranean colonisation and there are no adaptive characters in comparison with epigean specimens from the same geographical area. Specimens are quite large (pedipalpal chela of females 1.14–1.16 mm , movable chelal finger 0.75–0.77 mm ) and this fits the epigean specimens of
C. densedentatus
(Mt. Sirino, Potenza Province: pedipalpal chela of female 1.18 mm , movable chelal finger 0.77 mm ).
Chthonius ruffoi Caporiacco, 1951
is therefore proposed as a junior subjective synonym of
Chthonius densedentatus Beier, 1938
( n. syn. ).

For the discussion concerning the identity of
Chthonius rhodochelatus
, see Remarks under
C. ischnocheles
.

Among the species of the
Chthonius ischnocheles
group,
C. densedentatus
is morphologically similar to the epigean, widespread
C. ischnocheles
and the hypogean
C. nicolosii
from Sicily .
Chthonius densedentatus
differs from
C. ischnocheles
primarily in the following characters: posterior margin of carapace with 2 macrosetae and 2 lateral microsetae that are typically three times shorter than the median macrosetae (with 4 macrosetae, lateral setae as long or slightly shorter than the median ones in
C. ischnocheles
); fixed chelal finger at level of est-it with 5–7 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.013 –0.018 ( ♂ ) or 0.013 –0.023 ( ♀ ) mm (with 3–4 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.020 –0.034 ( ♂ ) or 0.023 –0.036 ( ♀ ) mm in
C. ischnocheles
); movable chelal finger at level of st-t with 5–8 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.012 –0.020 ( ♂ ) or 0.012 –0.022 ( ♀ ) mm (with 4–5 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.018 –0.023 ( ♂ ) or 0.018 –0.027 ( ♀ ) mm in
C. ischnocheles
). For comparison between
C. densedentatus
and
C. nicolosii
see Remarks under the latter species.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The citation of
Chthonius ischnocheles ruffoi
from Chiusazza cave, Syracuse ( Beier 1963a ) remains to be verified. Many Italian records of
C. ischnocheles
reported by Gardini (2000) are likely to be unverified misidentifications of
C. densedentatus .

Although previously only known from Bosnia and Herzegovina ,
Chthonius densedentatus
is newly recorded from France , Switzerland , Italy , Slovenia , Croatia , Albania and Greece .
